choices.text: Sagittal line down the midline of the neck

questions.text: Which of the following is not a border of the anterior triangle ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The anterior triangle of the neck is bounded laterally by the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid, superiorly by the inferior border of the mandible, and medially by the midline of the neck, not by the sternohyoid.

The anterior triangle is one of the main subdivisions of the neck, formed by specific anatomical borders.

  • Borders of the Anterior Triangle:
    • Lateral (Posterior) : Anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (Option A ruled out)
    • Medial : Midline of the neck (sagittal line from chin to sternum) (Option C ruled out)
    • Superior : Inferior border of the mandible (Option B ruled out)
  • It contains subdivisions like the submental, submandibular, carotid, and muscular triangles.
  • Muscles within the triangle (e.g., sternohyoid, omohyoid) do not form its border—they lie inside it and help further divide it.

questions.text: The bifurcation of the common carotid into the external carotid and internal carotid is seen in which triangle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The carotid triangle contains the bifurcation of the common carotid artery into internal and external carotid arteries, typically at the level of the superior border of the thyroid cartilage (C3–C4).

  • The carotid triangle is a subdivision of the anterior triangle of the neck and is clinically significant due to the major vascular and neural structures it contains.
    • Boundaries of the Carotid Triangle:
      • Anteriorly: Superior belly of omohyoid
      • Superiorly: Posterior belly of digastric
      • Posteriorly: Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid
    • Key Contents:
      • Common carotid artery (and its bifurcation)
      • External and internal carotid arteries
      • Internal jugular vein
      • Vagus nerve (CN X)
      • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
      • Ansa cervicalis
      • Carotid sinus and body

Explanation of other options:

Submental triangle (Option A): Lies in the midline below the chin; contains submental lymph nodes, not vascular bifurcations.

Submandibular triangle (Option B): Contains the submandibular gland, facial artery and vein, but not the carotid bifurcation.

Muscular triangle (Option D): Contains infrahyoid muscles, thyroid and parathyroid glands, but not the carotid bifurcation.

choices.text: The submental triangle is bounded laterally by the anterior belly of the digastric muscle and inferiorly by the hyoid bone.
The muscular triangle is bounded by the midline of the neck anteriorly, superior belly of omohyoid, and anterior border of sternocleidomastoid.
The digastric (submandibular) triangle is bounded superiorly by the posterior belly of digastric and inferiorly by the mandible.
The carotid triangle is bounded by the posterior belly of digastric, superior belly of omohyoid, and anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the boundaries of subdivisions of the anterior triangle of the neck is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The digastric triangle is bounded superiorly by the inferior border of the mandible, and anteroinferiorly and posteroinferiorly by the anterior and posterior bellies of the digastric muscle, respectively.

The anterior triangle is divided into four smaller triangles:

  • Submental triangle (Option A ruled out)
    • Boundaries:
      • Lateral: Anterior belly of digastric (both sides)
      • Inferior: Body of hyoid
      • Apex: Chin
      • Floor: Mylohyoid muscle
    • Muscular triangle (Option B ruled out)
      • Boundaries:
        • Midline of the neck (anterior)
        • Superior belly of omohyoid (superolateral)
        • Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid (inferolateral)
      • Digastric (Submandibular) triangle
        • Boundaries:
          • Superior: Inferior border of mandible
          • Anteroinferior: Anterior belly of digastric
          • Posteroinferior: Posterior belly of digastric
        • Carotid triangle (Option D ruled out)
          • Boundaries:
            • Superior: Posterior belly of digastric
            • Inferomedial: Superior belly of omohyoid
            • Posterolateral: Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid

questions.text: A patient who underwent surgery in the left carotid triangle complains of numbness over the anterior neck and difficulty swallowing. On examination, tongue movement is normal, but there is loss of touch over the skin of the anterior triangle. The surgeon suspects injury to nerves passing through the cervical plexus. Which of the following nerves is unlikely to be involved in this region?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The medial supraclavicular nerve innervates skin over the chest and shoulder, not the anterior triangle, making it the least likely to be involved.

Nerves typically found in or near the carotid triangle:

  • Transverse cervical nerve (C2-C3): Supplies skin of the anterior neck, hence likely to be injured. (Option A ruled out)
  • Ansa cervicalis: Motor innervation to infrahyoid muscles, runs in the carotid sheath, may be involved in swallowing issues. (Option B ruled out)
  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII): Although primarily motor to tongue, it carries fibers from C1 that contribute to ansa cervicalis, thus possibly involved. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: The clavicular and sternal heads of the sternocleidomastoid muscle
The anterior scalene muscle and the clavicular head of the sternocleidomastoid muscle
The anterior scalene muscle and the sternal head of the sternocleidomastoid muscle
The clavicle and the sternal head of the sternocleidomastoid muscle

questions.text: You are an intern in the Emergency department and have been closely monitoring a patient who was brought in earlier for cardiopulmonary arrest. The Emergency Medicine resident asks you to place a central venous catheter (line) in the right internal jugular vein. Which of the following external landmarks should be used in order to place the catheter?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The internal jugular vein is best accessed in the apex of the triangle formed between the clavicular and sternal heads of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

  • The internal jugular vein (IJV) lies deep to the sternocleidomastoid muscle and within the carotid sheath, lateral to the common carotid artery.
  • In clinical practice, a central line is often inserted at the apex of the triangle formed by the sternal and clavicular heads of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, typically at a 30°–45° angle directed toward the ipsilateral nipple.
  • This technique minimizes the risk of injury to surrounding structures and allows reliable entry into the IJV.

Explanation of other options:

Anterior scalene muscle and clavicular head of sternocleidomastoid muscle (Option B): Not an ideal landmark; anterior scalene is not a visible or palpable surface landmark.

Anterior scalene and sternal head of sternocleidomastoid muscle (Option C): Again, anterior scalene is deep and not used for surface-guided IJV access.

Clavicle and sternal head of sternocleidomastoid muscle (Option D): Does not define the triangle used for cannulation; both heads of SCM are needed.

questions.text: A patient presents with a lump in the front of your neck just below your Adam's Apple, hoarseness and dizziness when you raise your arms above your head. In which Anterior neck triangle is this gland found?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical vignette given above makes the diagnosis of goiter. The thyroid gland is located within the muscular triangle of the anterior neck, deep to the infrahyoid (strap) muscles.

The muscular triangle is one of the subdivisions of the anterior triangle of the neck.

  • It is bounded by:
    • Midline of neck
    • Superior belly of omohyoid
    • Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid
  • The thyroid gland lies deep within this triangle, beneath the sternohyoid and sternothyroid muscles.
  • Clinical clues:
    • A lump below the thyroid cartilage (Adam's apple) is likely thyroid swelling
    • Hoarseness is compression or involvement of the recurrent laryngeal nerve
    • Dizziness when raising arms is positive Pemberton’s sign, suggesting retrosternal goiter compressing venous return or trachea.

choices.text: Sternocleidomastoid; attaches to mastoid process of temporal bone
Omohyoid; attaches to superior border of scapula

questions.text: In the given image, identify the muscle marked A which forms the lateral boundary of the anterior triangle of the neck. Also, mention the most superior attachment of this muscle.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sternocleidomastoid (SCM) forms the lateral boundary of the anterior triangle, and its most superior attachment is on the mastoid process of the temporal bone.

The anterior triangle of the neck is bounded:

  • Laterally by the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle
  • Medially by the midline of the neck
  • Superiorly by the inferior border of the mandible

The SCM originates from two heads:

  • Sternal head: anterior surface of manubrium of sternum
  • Clavicular head: medial 1/3 of the clavicle

It inserts superiorly on the mastoid process of the temporal bone and lateral part of the superior nuchal line of the occipital bone.

The SCM divides the side of the neck into anterior and posterior triangles, making it a key landmark.

Explanation of other options:

Omohyoid (Option B): While the omohyoid is a strap muscle seen in the anterior triangle, it does not form the lateral boundary. It has two bellies connected by an intermediate tendon and originates from the superior border of the scapula, not the mastoid.

Sternocleidomastoid (Clavicular attachment) (Option C): This option incorrectly emphasizes the inferior (clavicular) attachment of SCM rather than the superior attachment, which is what the question asks. Hence, it's incorrect.

Sternohyoid (Option D): The sternohyoid is a strap muscle that lies medial and superficial to the thyroid gland and is part of the muscular triangle. It does not contribute to the boundary of the anterior triangle, nor does it reach the mastoid process.

questions.text: An abscess on the lateral aspect of the tongue drains into lymph nodes in which triangle ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral part of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue drains into the submandibular lymph nodes, which are located in the submandibular triangle.

  • Lymphatic drainage of the tongue depends on the specific part involved:
    • Tip of the tongue : Drains to submental lymph nodes
    • Lateral anterior two-thirds : Drains to submandibular lymph nodes
    • Medial anterior two-thirds : Drains bilaterally to deep cervical lymph nodes (especially jugulo-omohyoid)
    • Posterior third (base) : Drains directly into deep cervical nodes
  • The submandibular triangle contains:
    • Submandibular gland
    • Facial artery and vein
    • Submandibular lymph nodes
    • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
  • Since the lateral tongue drains into submandibular lymph nodes, an abscess here would result in swelling/tenderness in this triangle.

Explanation of other options:

Submental triangle (Option A): Drains the tip of the tongue and central lower lip; not the lateral aspect of the tongue.

Posterior triangle (Option C): Contains posterior cervical lymph nodes, mainly draining the posterior scalp and neck. Tongue lymphatics do not drain here.

Muscular triangle (Option D): Contains infrahyoid muscles, thyroid, larynx, and trachea. No direct involvement in tongue lymphatic drainage.

questions.text: Which of the following fascia provides structure to the lateral nasopharyngeal walls and helps maintain patency of the airway ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pharyngobasilar fascia is the part of the middle layer of deep cervical fascia that attaches pharynx to the skull base. The pharyngobasilar fascia provides structure to the lateral nasopharyngeal walls and helps maintain patency of the airway.

Attachments of the fascia are:

  • superiorly: basilar part of occipital bone and petrous temporal bone
  • inferiorly: superior pharyngeal constrictor muscle
  • anteriorly: posterior border of medial pterygoid plate
  • posteriorly: midline pharyngeal raphe

Explanation of other options:

Buccopharyngeal fascia (Option B): This fascia lies external to the pharyngeal muscular wall, forming part of the visceral layer of the pretracheal fascia, and allows movement of the pharynx during swallowing but does not provide internal structural support.

Prevertebral fascia (Option C): This fascia surrounds the vertebral column and associated muscles; it is posterior and unrelated to the structure or patency of the nasopharyngeal airway.

Pretracheal fascia (Option D): This fascia is limited to the anterior neck, enclosing the thyroid, trachea, and esophagus; it does not reach or influence the nasopharynx.

questions.text: A patient underwent parotid surgery and an intern who was assisting the surgeon accidentally injured the Great auricular nerve. Which boundary of the posterior triangle great auricular nerve is content of ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The great auricular nerve is a cutaneous branch of the cervical plexus that ascends in the superficial fascia, forming part of the roof of the posterior triangle.

Boundaries of the posterior triangle:

  • Anteriorly - the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid
  • Posteriorly - the anterior border of the trapezius
  • Inferiorly - the middle third of the clavicle
  • Roof - superficial fascia containing external jugular vein, posterior jugular vein, the investing layer of deep fascia and cutaneous nerves. The cutaneous nerves include:
    • Great auricular nerve
    • Lesser occipital nerve
    • Supraclavicular nerve
    • Transverse cutaneous nerve
  • Floor - the prevertebral fascia overlying splenius capitis, levator scapulae, and the scalene muscles

questions.text: A patient has been suffering from mumps for 15 days and now comes with complaints of pain, tenderness and redness. On examination, hard swelling of the salivary gland is found out. The patient also complains of fever and chills. With what triangle the given scenario is associated with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The submandibular (digastric) triangle contains the parotid gland, which is inflamed in mumps, making this triangle clinically relevant.

  • The digastric triangle, a subdivision of the anterior triangle of the neck, is bounded by:
    • Superiorly: Inferior border of the mandible
    • Anteriorly: Anterior belly of digastric
    • Posteriorly: Posterior belly of digastric
  • Contents include:
    • Submandibular gland (primary content)
    • Submandibular lymph nodes
    • Facial artery and vein
    • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
    • Mylohyoid nerve
  • In mumps (viral parotitis), swelling of the parotid gland (especially if progressing or complicated) may extend into or affect the digastric triangle, leading to the pain and swelling observed.
